Characterization of subgingival biofilms in patients with aggressive periodontitis by means of scanning electron microscopy, transmissions electron microscopy and confocal laser scanning microscopy.

Periodontitis is an inflammatory disease of the dental ligament, caused by bacterial biofilm along with the host immune response, which can lead to an irreversible loss of the teeth. Besides caries, periodontitis is regarded as the most frequent infection disease in the western hemisphere. In order to be able to examine periodontal biofilm without disruption, biofilm carriers were constructed and inserted into the periodontal pockets of patients with aggressive periodontitis. The biofilm formed on these carriers were subsequently documented with electron microscopic methods and the confocal laser scanning microscope (cLSM). Flagellated rods, treponemes and EPS-producing bacteria were observed among the first pioneers to colonize the carrier surface. In a second step, other bacteria were found adhering to these pioneers, forming mono-layered colonies. When large macro-colonies began to overlap at their edges, a coherent, multilayered biofilm with regional divergent morphotypes had eventually developed. Noteworthy is the frequency, with which flagellated rods were found in subgingival biofilms. On these occasions, it became evident, that it was typically the flagella, which adhered to other bacteria. The appearance of the exopolymeric substance (EPS) showed an unexpected variety, as reflected in the diameter and characteristic-staining pattern of EPS capsules on transmission electron microscopic (TEM) images. In co-aggregation events EPS played an important role, too. On these occasions, the EPS represented the "glue" between the co-aggregation partners, by means of which the bacterial cells were held in close neighborhood. Another aspect of co-aggregation could be demonstrated in a sequence of images showing the development of so-called ‚Äúcorn-cobs‚Ä?. In the final stage of the development the central long rod existed only as an empty cell torso, while all surrounding bacteria showed normal cytoplasm content. The evaluation of subgingival biofilm on their carriers proved a very heterogeneous picture. Even though the same morphotypes were usually found throughout the periodontal sites of one and the same patient, their proportional shares could vary considerably. This observation was even valid for adjacent periodontal sites. All together, only few universal rules could be established between the post-treatment success and the development of the microbiological community in terms of amount and composition. Six months after the initial periodontal treatment the carrier exhibited generally a noticeably lower total bacterial load; and coccus-like and pleomorphic rods were found more often. The attempt to compare clinical data with the respective microbial parameters resulted in a strong positive Spearman- correlation between the median total bacterial load per carrier and the proportional number of deep periodontal sites per patient.
